cooling again after the lamp was taken off,
the light within the tube changed its colour a
gain, while the spectrum of the second order 
was replaced by the spectrum of the first order.
There is a certain elevation of temperature 
at which the increased density of the vapour 
does not permit <s>to<\s> the discharge to pass;
the light within the tube [is] extinguish<s>es<\s>[ed]
but abruptely reappears after cooling.
38. Well defined bright lines constituting 
a fine Sulphur spectrum of the second 
order are obtained if moderate discharges 
of Ruhmkorff’s large induction coil are 
sent through the tube, the tube being slightly 
heated by means of an alcohol lamp and 
a small Leyden jar intercalated. At first 
the spectrum extends only from about 
the sodium line to H[beta]. One observes chiefly 
a characteristic group of 16 lines, followed 
at some distance by two separate lines.
The spectrum once developed persists even 
after taking off the lamp. When we con
tinue to heat the brightness of the group 
increases and <s>the<\s> its lines begin to expand 
while at the same time the hitherto black 
ground is coloured. The brilliancy may be 
increased <s>at<\s> [to] such an extent as to be 
inbearable to the eye. Beyond the 
Sodium line towards the red extremity,
new distinct lines appear among which 
we particularly distinguish a triple line,
